learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content: • Understand what data visualization is and why it is an essential tool in public health and epidemiologic practice

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content: • Describe risk factors in public health and how they are measured

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content: • Explore the Visualization Hub of the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content: • Describe the key components and considerations in graphing public health data

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content:
• The presentation of data in pictorial or graphical format
     - Can be interactive, allowing the user to change inputs and view the resulting patterns and trends

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content: • As computer technology has improved, data visualization has been brought to the forefront of corporate work and, more recently, of, public health practice

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content: • Large amounts of complex data can be better understand using visualizations as opposed to charts and tables

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content: • "A picture is worth a thousand words"

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content: • 1812-1813: Charls Minard (a civil engineer) created a map showing the movement of Napoleon's army into and out of Russia

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content: • Shows the army's path, including number of soldiers, temperature, and time

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content: • Allow individuals to comprehend information quickly and easily

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content: • Show patterns, relationships, and trends

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content: • Identifies newly emerging changes, hotspots, or outliers

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content: • Allows prediction of future events (through extrapolation, not modeling)

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content: • Communicates a story or a message

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content: • Analyses of politics, economics, sports, and anything else of popular concern

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content:
• A licensed feature of the New York Times online since 2010
     - Acquired by ABC News in April 2018

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content: • Has won numerous awards

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content:
• Look at the FiveThirtyEight website
     - Why is it so popular?

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content: • One of the reasons is the creativity they use in visually depicting data related to issues that are of concern or interests to the general public

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content: • Charts

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content: • Graphs

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content: • Maps

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content: • Infographics

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content: • Dashboards

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content: • Storyboards

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content: • The US Census Bureau compiles geographic and sociodemographic information on all US residents on a regular basis

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content: • One of its tools is a Data Visualization Gallery

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content:
• Open one of the visualization options that is of interest to you
     - Answer the questions displayed on the following slide

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content: • In two to three sentences, describe the data and the message that is being conveyed

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content: • Name two positive aspects of the chosen method of visualization

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content:
• Name two areas for improvement or challenges of your chosen visualization
     - Consider: how might you have done this differently?

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content: • Description: this is a time-trend map showing the US population without health insurance coverage from 2008 to 2015

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content:
• Positive aspects:
     - The map is engaging as it scrolls through the relevant years in a fairly rapid fashion
     - It is easy to spot the patterns, or geographic areas where coverage is particularly good or poor

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content:
• Areas for improvement:
     - There is no clear delineation of major policy changes, like the passing of the Affordable Cara Act
     - You do not see years next to each other, making it more difficult to compare

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content: • Understand your data

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content:
• Decide on the message or story you would like to Communicate
     - This must be tailored to your target audience

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content:
• Consider logistical details
     - Should it be interactive?
     - What is the computing access and power of your target audience?
     - How current or updated can you keep your visualization?

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content:
• Learn from others
     - numerous blogs, books and articles, and examples are available on the Internet
